title:
So i’m pretty sure Crowley watched Disney movies or at least Lion King. 
( Can’t stop picturing him sitting in the theater with a hat and sunglasses on to “hide” himself)

blog.name: crowleydear
blog.title: To the w o r l d
blog.description: Kieran/Ciarán / he/him / world's best whatever / Tolkien blog is @bifaramir

body:
Twin constants–an early summer’s evening

So I was talking to @not-so-good-omens and a ficlet happened… And I was encouraged to post it… So here it is, unedited gjskgkd! Hope it isn’t too terrible–have Aziraphale and Crowley sitting in a sand dune on the beach where I grew up

Aziraphale leaned onto the trunk of the wizened pine tree and dug a hand into the sand on top of the dune. Crowley watched the back of his head, curls seeming to be set on fire in the glow of the setting sun, reminiscent of the halo which had rested above them long ago, and sighed softly as the angel leaned into him. He wrapped an arm around him and listened to the sea rushing in, and was slowly drawn into that deep reflective contemplation which offered neither escape nor respite.

It had been six thousand years. Six thousand years of knowing each other and talking to each other and sharing drinks and food and then more drinks and sometimes more food after that. He’d heard every one of the angel’s spontaneous, idiosyncratic little thoughts, familiarized himself with every one of his habits and memorized every line in his face, and yet every day he spent with Aziraphale was another day he was happy to have known. Alone, he was in his element. He was cool, he was suave, he was always on top of everything. With Aziraphale, he was thrown off guard every other minute, he was tumbling through the strange feeling of perhaps, just maybe, not being the smartest person in the room, nor the most loved. He was whole, with the angel. He knew himself, and then he knew himself-with-Aziraphale. With the angel, he voiced doubts,admittedly through a thick veneer of faked cynical apathy, and was returned them twofold.

He could stay here forever with the angel under his arm, was complete with the angel, and could never have lived without him. Someone, had he really just thought that? Could he not live without Aziraphale? Maybe he couldn’t. Maybe not. He could surely see himself living with the angel forever… In their little lives while the world changed, with Aziraphale’s books and Crowley’s cool car and them, the twin constants of the human world throughout six millennia. He would set the world on fire for Aziraphale, he knew. But greater still than that, he would save the world for him. He already had, in a way. He loved humanity, loved the world, but always Aziraphale had brought it to light, in evenings spent in London bars getting drunk with Shakespeare, days in medieval Constantinople eating fruit on plush divans, sunrises in Ur where Aziraphale pointed out the shape of the ziggurats, said he’d been very proud of those, and Crowley remembered the commendation for future archeological bafflement he’d gotten. He would die for his angel, and now, he thought, he was living for his angel.

Always it had been this way, and always it would remain this way, and now the thought struck Crowley that, this way that he’d loved Aziraphale, had always been returned to him. That the warmth of Aziraphale’s smiles and the gentleness of his touch and the lilt of his laugh had led him along the same path at whose end, at the edge of the yellow wood of loving and living and knowing, Crowley now found himself. And Crowley allowed himself to sink into the comfortable warmth of the angel beneath him, and pressed a kiss into his curls, and was content to find that the kiss was returned into the crook of his neck as he saw the water shimmer beyond them, the last light of the sun disappearing to let the stars take its place, and the breeze being ever so slightly too cool for anyone not wrapped in the arms of another

title: Insecure
body:
And all who sat in the council looked intently at him, and they saw that his face was like the face of an angel-

“Your wings are an absolute mess, you know that?”

Aziraphale raised his head from a book he was reading.”Pardon?”

“Your wings, they look like you took a flight through a hurricane.” Crowley said with a chuckle and stood up, stretching his long limbs.

“I suppose,” Aziraphale simply shrugged and his focus returned back to his book. He could hear Crowley walking over to him and resting his hand over where his wings would be.

Angels become more and more beautiful the closer they get to the Lord: “I have seen faces of angels of the third heaven so beautiful that no painters, with all their skill, could render a fraction of their light with their pigments or rival a thousandth part of the light and life that show in their faces-”

“Doesn’t hurt to preen them from time to time, this isn’t a pretty look for an angel of the Lord.” The demon said with a smile and gently patted the angel on the back.

You are not beautiful.

He didn’t notice the way Aziraphale’s knuckles whitened at how tightly he held the book his hands.”You’re right, my dear.” He replied with a smile of his own.

As Crowley walked through the bookshop door, Aziraphale’s gaze silently followed him.

When the door closed behind his demon, the wings unfurled behind him and Aziraphale’s smile fell. He moved one of the wings in front of him and stared at the dishevelled feathers, plump fingers ran through the soft mess.

After a moment he stopped and with a sigh pulled the unfinished wings back.

“Such a silly thing,” he chuckled sadly to himself,”I’m not here to be pretty,”

He stood up and walked over to a nearby cabinet, placing back the book he was reading, once he closed it, he was met with his own reflection.

He looked away.

summary: I've just realised the way Sheen and Tennant describe their characters amuses me because in the books I always get the...
body: I’ve just realised the way Sheen and Tennant describe their characters amuses me because in the books I always get the impression that Crowley is the one showering Aziraphale with love-struck looks and trying not to show it (that’s really why he has the glasses) and Aziraphale is the one who is fucking irritated about loving Crowley but he does, he really does

blog.description: she, her | 20 | Poland | Christian | INFP | writer | gif in the header by @julia-the-fan | my Tolkien side blog: @sindar-princeling | writing side blog: @worldtrappedinaperson | contents vary depending on current obsessions

summary: Aziraphale is smart and logical, he does his taxes so well that people actually suspect he murdered someone, he manages to make...
body:
Aziraphale is smart and logical, he does his taxes so well that people actually suspect he murdered someone, he manages to make sense of Agnes’ prophecies, and is far from helpless when it comes to coming back to England from Heaven

Crowley is observant and intelligent, he analyses and questions the reality around him from the very beginning and out-smarts two dukes of hell, even though he had to come up with a plan on the spot

the thing about them is that neither of them is stupid so I can’t help but feel impressed by what has got to be their actual dedication to being so fucking stupid

blog.name: crowley-did-this
blog.title: Crowley's Crimes
blog.description: A comprehensive list of every minor inconvenience and annoyance the demon formerly known as Crawly is responsible for. submit your pet hates here so we can shame him for his sins

tags: i like this invention of his
body:
Crowley invented pomegranates

They’re delicious, annoying to get the seeds out of, and historically have caused quite a bit of trouble

tags: he was my first muse on this hellsite
i miss him a lot but i hate what canon did to him
i tried to write him again but i just couldnt get into it ya know
summary: ;; also legit why was the mystery that was crowley never explained. a demon with red smoke and the powers of archangels plus...
body: ;; also legit why was the mystery that was crowley never explained. a demon with red smoke and the powers of archangels plus multiple other powers that were never fully addressed. he was the only character to stay alive for as long as he did and i dont buy into the whole luck thing for a moment about how he became king of hell. you, as a lowly demon, do not luck into that position. i want to know who crowley REALLY was and how he REALLY came to be the king and i want to know what the fuck he actually was because i dont believe for a minute that he was simply a demon turned king. that’s all for now byeeeeeee

tags: it would be cool wouldn't it?
summary: Do we know what is going on in this scene? I can’t think on the top of my hat what it could be from the book so possibly...
caption:
Do we know what is going on in this scene? I can’t think on the top of my hat what it could be from the book so possibly something new?

By the picture in the background and the shape of the dark tall figure both gifs are from one scene.

In the first one Crowley has his hands tied and is approaching some kind of… altar? In the second one he is turning to see it - I think that the second gif happens before the first one, and it’s that ‘oh shit’ moment for Crowley. By the haircut and the glasses it is not in the past.

That got me thinking. We know that in 1943 Aziraphale tries to be clever which gets him into trouble with the Nazis and Crowley having to save him in a church, and I though it would be really neat if this would be a parallel - Crowley getting into trouble and Aziraphale having to go in some kind of demonic place to save him. :)

question: ☀️☀️A/C, body image issues Aziraphale?☀️☀️
answer:
My Ask | My Ko-Fi | My Ao3 | Requests always welcome!

Put a ☀️ and a prompt in my ask for a minifill!

The body of Ezra Fell - in stark contrast to the body of Anthony J. Crowley - had been selected to not draw attention. This was usually the case with his bodies: once upon a time, he’d pick big bodies he never really felt like he fit in, with muscle or bulk, that he might blend in amongst slaves; at other times, he would pick skinny, thin bodies of ageing tutors and clerks. Usually, unlike Crowley, he had tended toward older faces, but now…

He’s had this body for a little under two hundred years now.

He’d wanted to just fade into the background a bit, so he’d picked the usual age, in the fifties, gone for a white face and red cheeks, picked blond hair that was soft but bland in its colour, picked eyes that were blue, but with a watered-down colour. The Host liked it when you picked the “appropriate” things, but Aziraphale didn’t want to draw attention. And certain things helped with that, now that they were approaching the 21st century: he layered his clothing, hid his body, and the body itself was… well-padded. There were benefits, of course, in that he might eat as much as he pleased and not mind where it landed on his body, that he might favour his comfortable life of studious indolence. More and more, people looked away from bodies like the one he now favoured, with its heavy seat and thick thighs, its softness and its fat.

Not what he wanted to be ugly, per se, but certainly not handsome, certainly not attractive.

He didn’t have time for nonsense like that.

Especially in the Hyacinth and Vine, surrounded by all those poor young men in need of guidance, he hardly wanted to draw attention as a potential suitor. And he had, now and then, but he’d always gently put people off from him, but now…?

Now, things were different. Now, he had Crowley - had him. They slept together in the same bed, sometimes, at Crowley’s flat or at Aziraphale’s, and Aziraphale had even been looking at cottages in the South Downs, had even considered…

It was different, now. 

His body had never been selected for sexuality, but now, now there was sexuality, and intimacy, and romance, and Crowley was ever so chic. He liked his sleek, modern lines and his sleek, modern body, liked all of the thin furniture and his skinny volumes of poetry, his silks and sheer fabrics… 

When people saw him with Crowley, saw Crowley wound about his neck or his hips, saw Crowley kissing him or fussing over him or sitting in his lap, they looked… Aziraphale knew what they looked like. They’d looked like that for nearly a hundred years, and humans had their funny little suspicions, but now those suspicions were quite right, and when they looked at the two of them - looked at Aziraphale - with such disgust, revulsion, distaste…

“Crowley,” Aziraphale murmured, and Crowley’s eyes fluttered open, revealing sleepy, serpentine eyes, his chin resting on Aziraphale’s naked belly. He seemed to be spending an awful lot of time there, as of recent: sprawled over Aziraphale’s thighs or making use of his prominent gut as a pillow, melting over him… “Do you think, my dear, er– Merely that I know that you… Ought I, do you think…?”

Crowley blinked slowly, languorously. 

“Hm. Well. I might– I might lose some weight, dearheart, that’s all.”

Crowley raised his head, his lips downturning at their edges, his brow furrowing in what seems to be genuine perplexity. 

“Oh,” he said. His frown deepened with every moment, and his expression was a mix of baffled and, Aziraphale was thrown to note, disappointment. Crowley’s grip seemed to tighten as he wrapped his arms more around Aziraphale’s thighs, his fingers pressing into the thick meat of Aziraphale’s hips and squeezing plaintively. “Why?”

“Oh,” Aziraphale said. That was… That was slightly different. Not that it was all about Crowley, of course - this was Aziraphale’s body, of course, this was his own body. But Aziraphale’s sense of intimacy, of sexuality, was wound up in Crowley’s sinuous form, in his lithe body, his muscle– “No… No reason. Just… thinking about it.”

“Oh,” Crowley said again. “Do you… have to?”

“No.”

“S’your body, of course. Not that I’d… You know. Complain.”

“Of course.”

“Right. Just that… I like it… like this.” Crowley glanced down at Aziraphale’s  belly, away from his eyes, and muttered, “S’nice. It’s sexy.”

“Oh.”

“Yeah.”

“Right.”

“Yeah.”

“I will… give it some thought.” He didn’t ask why, Aziraphale noted. Crowley didn’t ask why. Did he know why? Did he mind? Did he… Crowley was kissing his belly all over, making obscene sounds as he did so, nipping at the flesh, and it was making it rather difficult to concentrate.

He would table these thoughts for later.

Not what he wanted to be ugly, per se, but certainly not handsome, certainly not attractive.

He didn’t have time for nonsense like that.

This was usually the case with his bodies: once upon a time, he’d pick big bodies he never really felt like he fit in, with muscle or bulk, that he might blend in amongst slaves; at other times, he would pick skinny, thin bodies of ageing tutors and clerks. Usually, unlike Crowley, he had tended toward older faces, but now…

He’s had this body for a little under two hundred years now.

He’d wanted to just fade into the background a bit, so he’d picked the usual age, in the fifties, gone for a white face and red cheeks, picked blond hair that was soft but bland in its colour, picked eyes that were blue, but with a watered-down colour. The Host liked it when you picked the “appropriate” things, but Aziraphale didn’t want to draw attention. And certain things helped with that, now that they were approaching the 21st century: he layered his clothing, hid his body, and the body itself was… well-padded. There were benefits, of course, in that he might eat as much as he pleased and not mind where it landed on his body, that he might favour his comfortable life of studious indolence. More and more, people looked away from bodies like the one he now favoured, with its heavy seat and thick thighs, its softness and its fat.

Not what he wanted to be ugly, per se, but certainly not handsome, certainly not attractive.

He didn’t have time for nonsense like that.

tags: I think Michael's got his Aziraphale going on look at the way he's swaying his hips lmfao

summary: Neil Gaiman saying there will be no romance in the TV series when the book was full of subtext is catalogued in my brain right...
body: Neil Gaiman saying there will be no romance in the TV series when the book was full of subtext is catalogued in my brain right next to JK Rowling pulling “canon” gay romance out of her ass, and I don’t like that because I actually like the Neil man.

reblog.comment: Neil Gaiman saying there will be no romance in the TV series when the book was full of subtext is catalogued in my brain right next to JK Rowling pulling “canon” gay romance out of her ass, and I don’t like that because I actually like the Neil man.
